g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
1. Introduction
Exposure to volcanic ash has been shown to exacerbate respiratory conditions and increase
hospital visits [
]. Arange of respiratory protection (RP) is recommendedanddistributedby agencies to
help protect affected citizens from inhaling ash during volcanic crises [
]. The effectiveness of RP is
dependent on several factors: (i) the design, to prevent penetration of a speciÔ¨Åc hazardous substance;
(ii) reduction of exposure to the level required to protect the wearer‚Äôs health; and iii) appropriateness
for the individual wearer, task, and environment [
In our previous research, Mueller et al. [
] reported the Ô¨Åltration efÔ¨Åciency (FE) of 17 types of RP
typically used during volcanic crises, tested in a laboratory setting. The median FE of individual RP
types for two volcanic ashes, combined, ranged considerably from23.4%for a veil fromIndonesia to
99.8% for an industry-certiÔ¨Åed FFP2 (N95-equiv.) mask [
]. Surgical masks, which were distributed
following the eruption of Kelud volcano in Indonesia in 2014 [
] had median FEs of 98.4% and a
‚ÄòÔ¨Çat-fold‚Äô mask also distributed in Indonesia by the Red Cross had a median FE of 98.1%. Steinle et al. [
reported the total inward leakage (TIL) of the four best performing masks (plus, a surgical mask was
tested with an added layer of material tied over the top) fromMueller et al. [
], which was assessed in
a laboratory volunteer simulation study. The N95-equiv. mask was reported to performsigniÔ¨Åcantly
better, (mean TIL 9%), compared to the other masks tested (>22% TIL), including the Surgical and
Flat-fold masks, which both had TIL of 35%. The volunteers also reported on the wearability and
perceived effectiveness of the masks tested. The N95-equiv. mask was perceived to provide the best
protection of the tested masks, but also was perceived as being uncomfortable and more difÔ¨Åcult to
breathe through. The Flat-fold and Surgical masks were both perceived to be the worst in terms of
protection, as they were thought to have lots of gaps and a poor Ô¨Åt, but to be the most comfortable
and breathable.
Whilst the results of the laboratory-based studies provided valuable information on the efÔ¨Åcacy of
RP typically used against volcanic ash, and their perceived effectiveness and wearability, there is
still a need to consider their acceptance and perceived performance in real-life settings by those
residing in communities affected by volcanic ash. Mount Sinabung, a volcano in North Sumatra,
Indonesia, has been continuously active since September 2013, producing extensive volcanic ash
clouds. These conditions provided a timely opportunity to test the wearability of RP used during
volcanic eruptions, in situ (in a hot, humid environment), for the Ô¨Årst time.
The aim of the current study was to identify which of the masks previously assessed in the
laboratory setting [
], were perceived to be most wearable by residents living in communities affected
by the Sinabung eruptions, based on criteria such as comfort, Ô¨Åt provided, and the ease of breathing
when worn, in addition to perceived effectiveness.
2. Methods
2.1. Volunteer Recruitment
A convenience sample was obtained of 30 volunteers aged between 18 and 65, with a mix of ages
and gender, who resided in areas affected by the Mount Sinabung volcanic ash. Potential volunteers
were excluded from participation, based on self-reports, if they were outside the 18‚Äì65 age range,
had cardiovascular or respiratory problems (e.g., asthma), suffered fromclaustrophobia, had mobility
issues or, in the case of female volunteers, were pregnant or breastfeeding. The volunteers, based on
self-reports, were to be Ô¨Åt enough to walk for about an hour (4
√ó
15-min with short breaks) at a
comfortable pace. Volunteers provided informed, written consent, and were informed that they could
leave the study at any time without giving a reason. At the end of the study, the volunteers had
the option of retaining the masks they had tested (along with a small cloth bag to keep them in) to
compensate themfor their time and any inconvenience caused.
